The curr_chunk is summarized as "SYSTEM." The Secretary of the Treasury will modify the Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System to facilitate corrections and compliance. Self-correction for plan loan errors will be available through the voluntary compliance program, meeting the requirements of the Voluntary Fiduciary Correction Program. The Secretary of the Treasury will update the Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System to include a correction program for retirement plans under section 457(b) of the Internal Revenue Code. Additionally, custodians of individual retirement plans will be able to address inadvertent errors without penalty. Under section 4974 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, waivers of the 60-day rollover deadline may be granted for reasons beyond the account owner's control. Nonspouse beneficiaries can return distributions to an inherited IRA in cases of inadvertent errors. The Secretary of the Treasury will expand the Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System to include corrections for required minimum distributions. The Treasury will expand the Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System to allow plans and custodians of individual retirement plans to self-correct errors without excise tax within 180 days. Additionally, specific correction methods will be established for errors in implementing automatic enrollment and escalation features. SEC. 241 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows for electronic communication of pension plan information. SEC. 241 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 permits electronic furnishing of pension plan documents to participants, beneficiaries, or specified individuals through designated electronic systems. SEC. 241 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows electronic delivery of pension plan documents to participants, beneficiaries, or specified individuals through designated electronic systems, ensuring proper notice and confidentiality of personal information. Participants or beneficiaries must not have chosen to receive a paper version of the document. Electronic delivery of pension plan documents is allowed under SEC. 241 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Participants or beneficiaries must be notified of their right to receive a paper version before documents are furnished electronically. The electronically provided document must adhere to style, format, and content requirements and include a notice of its significance. The term 'document' includes reports, statements, notices, notifications, and other information. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for electronic communication of pension plan information to participants, beneficiaries, or other individuals. Documents can be furnished electronically if the system allows access through electronic means. The amendment allows electronic communication of pension plan information to participants, beneficiaries, or individuals through various electronic means. The amendment permits electronic delivery of pension plan information to participants, beneficiaries, or individuals, ensuring confidentiality and offering the option for a paper version. The amendment allows electronic delivery of pension plan information to individuals, with a notice explaining the document's significance. Effective starting plan years after December 31, 2013. SEC. 242. Modification of deadlines for summary plan description updates. SEC. 242 modifies deadlines for updating summary plan descriptions under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Administrators must provide participants and beneficiaries with a copy of the summary plan description within specific timeframes, and update it every fifth year after the plan becomes subject to this part. The administrator must provide an updated summary plan description integrating all plan amendments made within a five-year period. If no amendments are made, this requirement does not apply. Additionally, for pension plans, an updated summary plan description must be provided 210 days after the end of each remedial plan review period. An updated summary plan description must be provided within 210 days after the end of each remedial plan review period, regardless of plan amendments. Any modifications or changes to the plan must also be summarized and furnished to participants and beneficiaries within the same timeframe. An updated summary plan description must be provided within 210 days after the end of each remedial plan review period, regardless of plan amendments. If there is a material reduction in covered services or benefits, a summary description of the modification must be given to participants and beneficiaries within 60 days of adoption, or at regular intervals of up to 90 days. The term 'remedial plan review period' refers to the cycle of review by the Secretary of the Treasury to ensure the pension plan meets the requirements of the Internal Revenue Code. The pension plan must meet the requirements of the Internal Revenue Code to be considered a qualified plan. The amendments made by this section apply to summary plan descriptions provided under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act for plan years starting after December 31, 2013. SEC. 243 amends the reporting requirements for small plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act by changing the participant threshold to those with an accrued benefit. SEC. 244 introduces fiduciary requirements for selecting annuity providers and contracts. These changes apply to plan years starting after December 31, 2013. Section 404 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act is amended to allow annuity providers to make payments guaranteed by a State guaranty association. This amendment applies to annuity contracts purchased after the date of enactment of the Act. TITLE III--INDIVIDUAL RETIREMENT INVESTMENT ADVICE REFORM

SEC. 301. TRANSFER TO SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY OF AUTHORITIES REGARDING INDIVIDUAL RETIREMENT PLANS. Section 102 of Reorganization Plan No. 4 of 1978 is amended to include regulations, rulings, opinions, and exemptions related to individual retirement accounts and annuities, as well as simplified employee pensions and simple retirement accounts. The Secretary of the Treasury will consult with the Securities and Exchange Commission to establish regulations on professional standards of care for brokers and investment advisors. The Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of Labor have joint authority to issue regulations. The Secretaries of the Treasury and Labor have joint authority to issue regulations defining terms in the Code or ERISA. The amendments made by this section apply to regulations not finalized as of July 8, 2013. Any final regulation, ruling, opinion, or exemption issued by the Secretary of Labor before July 9, 2013, described in Reorganization Plan No. 4 of 1978, shall remain in effect until revoked or modified under the amendments made by this section.
